title: N. Hlubek
text:
Welcome to my personal website!
I a PhD student in Epidemiology at the University Medical Center Utrecht, with a background in psychological research and social policy. My current research focuses on leveraging large nationwide data to investigate Socioeconomic differences in environmental health inequalities.

title: Temporal Trends in Air Pollution Exposure across Socioeconomic Groups in The Netherlands
text: Air pollution exposure has been linked to detrimental health outcomes. While cross-sectional studies have demonstrated socioeconomic disparities in air pollution exposure, longitudinal evidence on these disparities remains limited. The current study investigates trends in residential air pollution exposure across socioeconomic groups in the Netherlands from 2014 to 2019.

title: Cross-country differences in the association between socioecnomic status and adolescent mental health
text: This project was my Master Thesis for the MSc. in Social Policy and Public Health at Utrecht University. We examined the association between adolescent socioeconomic status (SES), national-level mental health policies and adolescent mental health outcomes using data from 11-15 year-olds from 30 European Countries (n = 155.375).

title: A social identity approach to COVID-19 transmission in hospital settings
text:
We show the importance of the association between social identity processes and reduced risk perception and highlight the relationship between transparent communication strategies and self-reported adherence to COVID-19 guidelines, identity leadership and trust in leaders to manage COVID-19 appropriately.


An exploratory factor analysis with varimax rotation (maximum likelihood) was carried out using the psych package version 2.1.6 (Revelle, 2021) to ensure all items were clustering onto the appropriate factors. Descriptive statistics, including the correlations between the variables were obtained. The Lavaan package version 0.6-9 (Rosseel, 2021) was used to perform a mediation analysis using structural equation modelling (SEM), with 95% bias-corrected and accelerated (BCA) confidence intervals. Both models provided the regressions between each variable, the direct effects, the simple mediations via each mediator, and respectively the sequential mediation via both mediators in the second model.
A bootstrapped Sobel test was conducted to assess the significance levels of significant mediation effects using the bmem package version 1.8 (Zhang & Wang, 2020) with 10,000 bootstrapped samples and 95% BCA confidence intervals. The variables were inputted in this test in the same order as the previous mediation models. An alpha level of  = .05 was used for all statistical tests.

title: A social identity approach to COVID-19 transmission in hospital settings
text: If applicable, provide a code snippet here or mention where the code can be found (e.g., GitHub repository).

title: A social identity approach to COVID-19 transmission in hospital settings
text:
Methodology

Exploratory Factor Analysis: Conducted using the psych package in R to identify item clusters.
Mediation Analysis: Performed using the Lavaan package in R to explore relationships between variables.
Bootstrapped Sobel Test: Used to assess mediation effects with 10,000 samples for robustness.

title: A social identity approach to COVID-19 transmission in hospital settings
text:
Presentations
This project was presented at the following important instances:

N. Hlubek, A. Templeton (2022). Social identity processes in hospital workers risk perception and adherence to safety guidance during the COVID-19 pandemic. Paper presented at the BPS Social Psychology Section Annual Conference, 2022
N. Hlubek, A. Templeton (2021). A social identity approach to COVID-19 transmissions in hospital settings – Barriers and avenues to safe behaviour in healthcare workers. Project presented to the Scottish Government COVID-19 Nosocomial Review Group, 2021

title: Cross-country differences in the association between socioecnomic status and adolescent mental health
text: This project was my Master Thesis for the MSc. in Social Policy and Public Health at Utrecht University. We examined the association between adolescent socioeconomic status (SES), national-level mental health policies and adolescent mental health outcomes using data from 11-15 year-olds from 30 European Countries (n = 155.375).

title: Cross-country differences in the association between socioecnomic status and adolescent mental health
text:
Methodology

Multilevel regression analysis: Conducted using the lme4 and lmerTest package in R.

We used two-level linear regression models to investigate (1) overall associations between family affluence and adolescent mental health outcomes (2) overall associations between national-level policy indicators and adolescent mental health outcomes (3) cross country variations in the association between family affluence and adolescent mental health outcomes (4) the moderating role of national-level policy indicators on the association between family affluence and adolescent mental health outcomes.

title: Cross-country differences in the association between socioecnomic status and adolescent mental health
text:
Presentations
This project was presented at the following important instances:

N. Hlubek, A. Templeton (2022). Social identity processes in hospital workers risk perception and adherence to safety guidance during the COVID-19 pandemic. Paper presented at the BPS Social Psychology Section Annual Conference, 2022
N. Hlubek, A. Templeton (2021). A social identity approach to COVID-19 transmissions in hospital settings – Barriers and avenues to safe behaviour in healthcare workers. Project presented to the Scottish Government COVID-19 Nosocomial Review Group, 2021

title: Cross-country differences in the association between socioecnomic status and adolescent mental health
text:
Project Overview
This project, funded by the Scottish Government, aimed to understand the barriers healthcare workers (HCWs) faced in adhering to COVID-19 safety guidelines. The research explored how psychological group processes influenced perceived risk of COVID-19 and adherence to safety measures in hospital settings.

Bootstrapped Sobel Test: Used to assess mediation effects with 10,000 samples for robustness.

title: Temporal Trends in Air Pollution Exposure across Socioeconomic Groups in The Netherlands
text: Air pollution exposure has been linked to detrimental health outcomes. While cross-sectional studies have demonstrated socioeconomic disparities in air pollution exposure, longitudinal evidence on these disparities remains limited. The current study investigates trends in residential air pollution exposure across socioeconomic groups in the Netherlands from 2014 to 2019.

title: Temporal Trends in Air Pollution Exposure across Socioeconomic Groups in The Netherlands
text:
Methodology
Our dataset includes over 12.5 million individuals, aged 18 years and above, who resided in the Netherlands between 2014 and 2019, using Statistics Netherlands data. The address-level air pollution concentrations were estimated by dispersion models of the National Institute of Public Health and the Environment. We linked the exposure estimations of particulate matter < 10 or <2.5 μm (PM10, PM2.5) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2) to household-level socioeconomic data.

title: Temporal Trends in Air Pollution Exposure across Socioeconomic Groups in The Netherlands
text:
Presentations
This project was presented at the following important instances:

N. Hlubek, A. Templeton (2022). Social identity processes in hospital workers risk perception and adherence to safety guidance during the COVID-19 pandemic. Paper presented at the BPS Social Psychology Section Annual Conference, 2022
N. Hlubek, A. Templeton (2021). A social identity approach to COVID-19 transmissions in hospital settings – Barriers and avenues to safe behaviour in healthcare workers. Project presented to the Scottish Government COVID-19 Nosocomial Review Group, 2021

title: Temporal Trends in Air Pollution Exposure across Socioeconomic Groups in The Netherlands
